hedline.hl2: A Lot of Money From Not So Many

block.p: If money talks in politics, then 10 metropolitan areas around the country are talking very loudly.

The latest campaign-finance reports show that those 10 areas -- five on the East Coast, two on the West Coast, and three in the nation's vast interior -- have contributed close to two-thirds of all the money collected by the presidential candidates.

If money talks in politics, then 10 metropolitan areas around the country are talking very loudly.

The latest campaign-finance reports show that those 10 areas -- five on the East Coast, two on the West Coast, and three in the nation's vast interior -- have contributed close to two-thirds of all the money collected by the presidential candidates.
That's $68.7 million of roughly $116 million raised from individuals so far, with 19 months still to go before the election.

Those 10 metropolitan statistical areas, out of more than 900 recognized by the United States Census Bureau, contain a quarter of the nation's population and took in slightly less than a third of the country's income in 2005.

They have tilted strongly toward Democrats so far, giving 63 percent of their contributions to the party's candidates. Nationwide, 58 percent of the contributions have gone to Democrats. Excluding the top 10, the number drops to 52 percent.

The New York metropolitan area ranked No. 1. Three ZIP codes on the East Side of Manhattan -- 10021, 10022 and 10128 -- ranked as the top three in the nation in contributions to Democrats, for a total of $3 million. For Republicans, ZIP codes 10021 and 10022 ranked first and second, as well, with ZIP code 85253, in Paradise Valley, Ariz., at No. 3. Combined, they contributed nearly $1.7 million to Republican candidates.
In all, the 10 metropolitan areas taken together gave $1.22 for each voting-age resident. There was considerable difference among them, though.

The affluent Bridgeport-Norwalk-Stamford area, in Connecticut, easily led in per capita giving, kicking in $3.60 for every voting-age resident. The seven areas on the East and West Coasts in the top 10 all exceeded $1 per capita. The three from interior states -- Chicago, Dallas and Houston -- all gave less than $1 per voting-age resident.
Republicans outpaced Democrats in only three of the top 10 areas -- Boston, Dallas-Fort Worth and Houston.
